{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Diana_MSG.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 240px | title = Diana (second version) | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]] | year = 1892-1893 | type = copper sheeting | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 14.5 | height_inch = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Philadelphia]] | museum = [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] | coordinates = | owner = }}
'''''Diana''''' – also known as '''''Diana of the Tower''''' – is an [[Cultural icon|iconic]] statue by sculptor [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]]. Once a famous New York City landmark, the second version stood atop the tower of [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]] from 1893 to 1925. Since 1932, it has been in the collection of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]].
The statue represents the goddess [[Diana (mythology)|Diana]].
==First version (1891-1892)== ''Diana'' was commissioned by architect [[Stanford White]] as a [[weather vane]] for the tower of Madison Square Garden, a theater-and-dining complex at [[26th Street (Manhattan)|26th Street]] and [[Madison Avenue]] in Manhattan. He talked his friend Saint-Gaudens into creating it at no charge, and picked up the cost of materials.<ref name="auto">"The Architect of Desire: Beauty and Danger in the Stanford White Family," Suzanna Lessard</ref> Model Julia "Dudie" Baird posed for the body of the statue.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Models/Dudie.htm</ref> Its face is that of Davida Johnson Clark, Saint-Gaudens's long-time model and mother of his illegitimate son Louis.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/17571 Davida Johnson Clark], from Metropolitan Museum of Art.</ref>
The first version – built by the [[W. H. Mullins Manufacturing Company]] in [[Salem, Ohio]] – was {{convert|18|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall and weighed {{convert|1800|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Monuments/Ideal/Diana1.htm</ref> Saint-Gaudens's design specified that the figure appear to delicately balance on its left toe atop a ball. However, the Ohio metal shop was unable to pass the rotating rod through the toe, so the design was altered and the figure instead was poised (less-gracefully) on its heel.
''Diana'' was unveiled atop Madison Square Garden's tower on September 29, 1891. The 304-foot (92.66 m) building had been completed a year earlier, and was the second-tallest in New York City. But the addition of the statue made it the city's tallest, by 13 feet (3.96 m).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JVzYO1TyZ6AC&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=madison+square+garden+tower+height&source=bl&ots=yk6wC1Fcyd&sig=mHLM8zLgVHCygH_8JP3I35PvQak&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBmoVChMIy-ydxsf5yAIVCmg-Ch26cwHp#v=onepage&q=madison%20square%20garden%20tower%20height&f=false Joseph J. Korum, ''The American Skyscraper, 1850–1940'' (2008)]</ref> The figure's billowing copper [[foulard]] (scarf) was intended to catch the wind, but the statue did not rotate smoothly because of its weight. ''Diana''{{'}}s nudity offended [[morality|moral crusader]] [[Anthony Comstock]] and his [[New York Society for the Suppression of Vice]].<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s9l5TIzarCUC&pg=PT61&dq=american+eve+the+statue&hl=en&ei=iYm5TtDtMaOQsALkvejZCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false| title=American Eve: Evelyn Nesbit, Stanford White, the Birth of the "It" Girl, and the Crime of the Century | author= Paula Uruburu| publisher= Penguin| year= 2009| isbn= 978-1-59448-369-1}}</ref> To placate Comstock and to increase the likelihood of its catching the wind, Saint-Gaudens draped the figure in cloth, but the cloth blew away.<ref>Federal Writers' Project. ''New York City Guide''. New York: Random House, 1939 {{ISBN|0-403-02921-X}} (Reprinted by Scholarly Press, 1976; often referred to as WPA Guide to New York City), pp.330–333</ref>
Soon after installation, both White and Saint-Gaudens concluded that the figure was too large for the building, and decided to create a smaller, lighter replacement. Following less than a year atop the tower, the statue was removed and shipped to Chicago to be exhibited at the 1893 [[World's Columbian Exposition]]. New Yorker W. T. Henderson wrote a [[tongue-in-cheek]] poetic tribute – "Diana Off the Tower" – a play on both the statue's name and situation.<ref>W. T. Henderson, [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/09/18/106890362.pdf "Diana Off the Tower" (PDF),] ''The New York Times'', September 18, 1892.</ref>
Saint-Gaudens served as head of the Chicago exposition's sculpture committee. His initial plan had been to place ''Diana'' atop the Women's Pavilion, but the city's [[Women's Christian Temperance Union]] protested and insisted that the controversial nude figure be clothed.<ref name="auto"/> Instead, it was placed atop the Agricultural Building.
The original ''Diana'' does not survive. In June 1894, eight months after the exposition's closing, a major fire tore through its buildings. The lower half of the statue was destroyed; the upper half survived the fire, but was later lost or discarded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jssgallery.org/other_artists/augustus_saint-gaudens/diana_of_the_tower.html|title=Augustus Saint-Gaudens' Diana of the Tower|first=|last=Natasha|publisher=}}</ref> <gallery> File:Davida Johnson Clark by Saint-Gaudens 1886.jpg|''Bust of Davida Johnson Clark'' (1886) by Saint-Gaudens. File:Diana 1st Version.jpg|First version of ''Diana'' in the foundry of the W. H. Mullins Manufacturing Company, Salem, Ohio, 1891. File:Agricultural Building (3572762953).jpg|Atop the Agriculture Building, World's Columbian Exposition, Chicago, 1893. </gallery>
==Second version (1893-present)== [[File:Madison Square Garden Diana.jpg|thumb|right|Second version of ''Diana'' with her copper foulard.]] ''Diana'' was completely redesigned by Saint-Gaudens – with a more elegant pose, a different thrust to the body, a thinner figure, smaller breasts and a more graceful angle to the leg. To better fit the proportions of Madison Square Garden's tower, the statue's height was scaled down to 14.5 feet (4.4 m).<ref>The Philadelphia Museum of Art's website lists the height of the figure as 13 ft 1 in (398.8 cm), and the height of the ball as 17 in (43 cm).[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/44513.html?mulR=241195760|1]</ref> The second version was made of hollowed copper, and weighed 700 lb (318 kg) – more than 60% less than the first version – light enough to rotate with the wind. As Saint-Gaudens originally envisioned, the figure was balanced on its left toe atop a ball. The statue was hoisted to the top of the tower on November 18, 1893.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1893/11/18/109733483.pdf| title=New Diana of the Tower| work=The New York Times| date=November 18, 1893}}</ref>
During the day, the gilded figure caught the sun and could be seen from all over the city and as far away as New Jersey. Electric lights, then a novelty, illuminated it at night; it was the first statue in history to be lit by electricity.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Monuments/Ideal/Diana2.htm</ref>
Madison Square Garden was slated to be demolished in 1925, to make way for construction of the [[New York Life Building]]. Prior to the building's demolition, ''Diana'' was removed and put in storage. The intention was for the statue to remain in New York City, however a seven year search to find a place to display it proved futile. In 1932, the [[New York Life Insurance Company]] presented ''Diana'' to the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] as a gift. It remains there today, displayed on the balcony of the museum's Great Stair Hall.<ref>[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/44513.html?mulR=967189961|8 Object record] in the Philadelphia Museum of Art's online collection.</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Philadelphia Museum greatstairhall.jpg| thumb|left|Saint-Gauden's second version of "Diana" on display in the Great Stair Hall of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. This is the same statue that sat atop Madison Square Garden from 1893 until the building was demolished in 1925.{{Deletable image-caption|date=May 2012}}]] -->
===Restoration=== [[File:Diana of the Tower Philadelphia Museum of Art cropped.jpg|thumb|left|Second version of ''Diana'' (restored, 2013-14), Philadelphia Museum of Art.]] When ''Diana'' was removed from Madison Square Garden in 1925, much of its gilded exterior was gone, having eroded away over three decades of exposure to the elements. The Philadelphia Museum of Art cleaned and repaired the statue in 1932, but the gold leaf was not replaced.
In 2013, scaffolding was constructed around the statue in the museum's Great Stair Hall for a year-long restoration. Conservators carefully cleaned its copper surface with chemicals and steam, removing nearly a century of dirt and grime. Samples of the small patches of remaining gold leaf on the statue were taken in an effort to match the carat, weight and color with its replacement. The statue's surface was then repaired and regilded with 180 square feet of gold leaf. Because it was known from contemporary sources that Saint-Gaudens did not like the look of bright gold at eye level, the conservators matted the gilding to reduce the glare and museum lighting designers adjusted the display lights for the interior display.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philamuseum.org/conservation/21.html|title=Philadelphia Museum of Art - Research : Conservation|first=Philadelphia Museum of|last=Art|publisher=}}</ref>
On July 14, 2014, the restored statue was unveiled and rededicated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-2687882/Philadelphia-museums-golden-goddess-glows-again.html#ixzz3mOfi0n9r|title=Philadelphia museum's golden goddess glows again|publisher=}}</ref>
===Cultural references===
In the popular 1975 novel ''[[Ragtime (novel)|Ragtime]]'', author [[E.L. Doctorow]] suggests in a single line that showgirl [[Evelyn Nesbitt]] had posed for the second version of the ''Diana'' statue. Having grown up poor in the streets of a Pennsylvania coal town, Nesbitt had risen up to become “the Gaudens statue Stanny White had put at the top of the tower of Madison Square Garden, a glorious bronze nude Diana, her bow drawn, her face in the skies.”
The 1981 film version of [[Ragtime (film)|''Ragtime'']] expanded upon this incident as the cause of a major conflict between Stanford White and Nesbitt's millionaire husband [[Harry K. Thaw]]. In the film, Thaw demands that the statue be taken down from the top of the Garden as it is an embarrassment to him. The character is seen glaring angrily at the statue before shooting White to death at the Rooftop Theatre at [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]] on June 25, 1906.
Both situations are completely fictional. The second version of ''Diana'' was placed atop the tower in 1893, when Nesbitt was only about nine years old, and eight years before she was introduced to White. {{clear}}
==Other versions==
===Half-sized statues=== [[File:Swanson4715.jpg|thumb|Half-sized ''Diana'' (1928), [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].]] [[Stanford White]] was so pleased with the 1893 second version that he asked Saint-Gaudens to create a half-sized copy in cement. This was installed in 1894 in the garden of White's Long Island estate, [[Box Hill Estate|Box Hill]], where it stood for many years. For the half-sized copy, Saint-Gaudens poised the figure on a half-ball. White's cement statue later was used to produce two bronze casts in 1928, and six bronze casts in 1987.<ref>John H. Dryfhout, ''The Works of Augustus Saint-Gaudens'' (UPNE, 2008), cat. 154, p. 207.</ref> The cement statue is now in the collection of the [[Amon Carter Museum of American Art]].<ref>[http://artmuseum.princeton.edu/collections/objects/33417 Diana], from Princeton University Art Museum.</ref> * [[Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site]], plaster. Saint-Gaudens's 1894 model. * Amon Carter Museum of American Art, cement. Stanford White's 1894 copy. * 1928 casts ** [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], gilded bronze ** Bass Hall, Fort Worth, Texas, bronze * 1987 casts ** [[Madison Square Garden]], New York City, bronze ** [[Brookgreen Gardens]], bronze<ref>http://www.brookgreen.org/AugustusSaint-Gaudens.cfm</ref> ** [[Princeton University Art Museum]], bronze<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!420595~!22&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Diana (Princeton University)], from SIRIS.</ref> ** Private collection, Saint-James, New York, bronze ** Private collection, Chicago, Illinois, bronze ** Private collection, Santa Fe, New Mexico, bronze
===Statuettes=== [[File:Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site SAGA2182.jpg|thumb|Statuette (foreground) and half-sized plaster model (background), [[Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site]].]] The [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] owns a bronze statuette of Saint-Gaudens's first version of ''Diana''.<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!293600~!11&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 ''Diana'' (first version)], from SIRIS.</ref>
Capitalizing on the popularity of the second version, Saint-Gaudens modeled statuettes in two sizes: 31 inches (78 cm), with the figure poised on a half-ball, and 21 inches (53 cm), with the figure poised on a full ball. These were cast in bronze beginning in 1899, and vary in the configuration of bow, arrow, string, hair, patination, and base.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1985.353|title=Diana - Augustus Saint-Gaudens - 1985.353 - Work of Art - Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History - The Metropolitan Museum of Art|publisher=}}</ref> * [[National Gallery of Art]], bronze<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/collection/sculpture/noflash/zone1-3.htm|title=NGA Sculpture Galleries|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], bronze * [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], bronze<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/diana-saint-gaudens-augustus|title=Diana|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!26038~!124&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus ''Diana'', (sculpture)]. ''SIRIS''</ref> * [[Cleveland Museum of Art]], bronze<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!12453~!117&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus ''Diana'', (sculpture)]. ''SIRIS''</ref> * [[Williams College Museum of Art]], bronze * Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site, bronze * [[New York Historical Society]], bronze * [[Brooklyn Museum]], bronze<ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/259/Diana_of_the_Tower Diana of the Tower], from Brooklyn Museum.</ref> * other museum and private collections.
===Busts and heads=== In 1908, the sculptor's widow authorized a posthumous casting of nine busts based on Saint-Gaudens's 31-inch (78 cm) statuette.<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1446K2BT31887.1258&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!349897~!16&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Diana (bust)], from SIRIS.</ref> A 7-3/8 in (18.7 cm) plaster bust is at Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site. Bronze busts are at the [[Carnegie Museum of Art]],<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!12723~!5&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 ''Diana of the Tower'' (bust)], from SIRIS.</ref> and in private collections.
Bronze casts of ''Diana'' 's head are at Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site;<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!18560~!114&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus Diana, (head)], from SIRIS.</ref> [[Harvard University]];<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!10490~!1&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Head of Diana], from SIRIS.</ref> and elsewhere.

revision.comment: /* List of persons buried in the Ducal Crypt */ Names corrected according to Reifenscheid, Richard: Die Habsburger in Lebensbildern, Styria Verlag 1982
revision.text: [[File:Wien - Stephansdom (2).JPG|thumb|Stephansdom in [[Vienna]], Austria, which houses the Ducal Crypt]] [[File:Wien - Stephansdom, Herzogsgruft.JPG|thumb|Ducal Crypt]] The '''Ducal Crypt''' ({{lang-de|Herzogsgruft}}) is a burial chamber beneath the [[chancel]] of [[St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna|Stephansdom]] in [[Vienna]], Austria. It holds 78 containers with the bodies, hearts, or [[viscera]] of 72 members of the [[House of Habsburg]]. ==History== Before his death at age 25 in 1365, Duke [[Rudolf IV of Austria|Rudolf IV]]{{Bioxref|3}} had ordered a crypt to be built for his remains in the new cathedral he commissioned, and it has sheltered those remains for over 650 years. He also ordered a [[cenotaph]] for himself to be placed upstairs above the crypt, in front of the high altar. That [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927202420/http://www.deca-forum.net/deca-cgi/query.pl?DEF=c%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Chida&DATEN=C%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Cdata&THE=C%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Cidx&USER=bild&BAG=20&POS=0&DOK_TPL=deca_doc.tpl&LIST_TPL=deca_list.tpl&FCT=q&iftxt=rudolfsgrab&N_ftxt=0&R_ftxt=%3D&ikufo=&N_kufo=1&R_kufo=%3D&i024=wien&N_024=2&R_024=%3D&i031=&N_031=3&R_031=%3D&i029=&N_029=4&R_029=%3D&iauen=&N_auen=5&R_auen=%3D&i039=&N_039=6&R_039=%3D& symbolic tomb] was later moved to the north choir and his [[epitaph]] written in secret symbols was placed on the wall of that choir. The family of the [[Habsburg#Dukes of Austria|ruling line of Austrian dukes]] was buried here after Rudolf IV, but after the dynasty became emperors they were buried in various cities (Vienna was not yet the settled seat of the emperor). After the [[Imperial Crypt]] at the [[Kapuzinerkirche]] opened in 1633, it became the new dynastic burial place. [[Image:StephansdomCatacombsLabeledPlan-en.png|left|thumb|The Ducal Crypt (red letters) is one of several burial locations beneath Stephansdom. The bones of over 11,000 persons from cemeteries formerly around the church are stored in the Catacombs.]] Embalmers have known since the time of the [[Ancient Egypt]]ians that it is necessary to remove the internal organs if the rest of the body is to be preserved. The containers with those organs were usually put in the coffin, but when the heir to the Imperial Throne, [[Ferdinand IV of Germany|King Ferdinand IV of the Romans]], died in 1654, he specified in his will that the container with his heart be placed in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]], his body in the [[Imperial Crypt|Imperial Crypt in the Kapuzinerkirche]], and the urn with his viscera in the crypt at the [[Stephansdom]]. His instructions resulted in the foundation of the [[Herzgruft]] at the Augustinerkirche. His younger brother, Emperor [[Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold I]], pursued a tradition imitating that distribution of remains, and also enlarged the Imperial Crypt to make it large enough for additional future burials. The urns with viscera were thereafter regularly deposited in the Ducal Crypt in the Stephansdom. There are now 33 persons who are each buried in all three places. By 1754 the small rectangular Ducal Crypt was overcrowded with 12 sarcophagi and 39 urns, so the area was expanded with an oval chamber being added (directly beneath the present location of the [[Throne#Ecclesiastical thrones|Archbishop's Throne]]) beyond the east end of the rectangular one. New sarcophagi were made for some of the bodies. In 1956 the crypt was renovated and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20071009144156/http://www.deca-forum.net/deca-cgi/getdoc.pl?DEF=c%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Chida%3BDATEN%3DC%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Cdata%3BTHE%3DC%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Cidx%3BUSER%3Dbild%3BDOK_TPL%3Ddeca_doc.tpl%3BLIST_TPL%3Ddeca_list.tpl%3BFCT%3Dg%3Biftxt%3Dherzogsgruft%3BN_ftxt%3D0%3BR_ftxt%3D%3D%3Bikufo%3D%3BN_kufo%3D1%3BR_kufo%3D%3D%3Bi024%3Dwien%3BN_024%3D2%3BR_024%3D%3D%3Bi031%3D%3BN_031%3D3%3BR_031%3D%3D%3Bi029%3D%3BN_029%3D4%3BR_029%3D%3D%3Biauen%3D%3BN_auen%3D5%3BR_auen%3D%3D%3Bi039%3D%3BN_039%3D6%3BR_039%3D%3D&KEY=fot%20w0008329 contents] were rearranged. The [[sarcophagi]] of Duke Rudolf IV{{Bioxref|3}} and his wife{{Bioxref|4}} were placed upon a pedestal and the 62 urns containing organs were moved from the two rows of shelves around the new section to cabinets in the original chamber. Deposition in the crypt has not always been permanent. Emperor [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]] lay here for only 20 years after his death, until his magnificent tomb upstairs in the south choir was ready. The body of his brother, Archduke [[Albert VI, Archduke of Austria|Albert VI]], was removed after 300 years. [[Image:Stephansdom Ducal Vault Orientation 1758.png|thumb|The old and new chambers of the crypt are adjacent, with a tunnel for daylight at the east (left) end, and stairs descending to the crypt's old chamber from the west.]] The greatest influx, other that the regular arrival of visceral urns, came as a result of the Austrian version of the [[Dissolution of the Monasteries|Dissolution of the English Monasteries]] under Emperor [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]] in 1782. When the religious institutions holding bodies of some of the members of the dynasty were closed, they needed to be moved. The Imperial Crypt at that time had only half the space it has today, and already held 57 bodies. The emperor ordered that the bodies of two persons{{Bioxref|1}} {{Bioxref|14}} who had died before the Imperial Crypt opened be brought to the Ducal Crypt instead. Another person, Empress Eleanor,{{Bioxref|16}} would normally have been entitled to space in the Imperial Crypt, but because her husband{{Bioxref|19}} was not buried there either, her body was sent to the Ducal Crypt. It is probably around this time that the body of Duke [[Albert VI, Archduke of Austria|Albert VI]] was removed to make room for others, and that the body{{Bioxref|15}} whose sarcophagus is inscribed with only the year and name of the parents arrived. Identified through other evidence as one-year-old Anna of Lorraine, it is known that her brother [[Charles V, Duke of Lorraine]] married Archduchess [[Eleanora Maria of Austria|Eleanora Maria Josepha]] (1653–1697) (widowed Queen of Poland and daughter of Emperor [[Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand III]]){{Bioxref|21}} in 1678, and that marriage may have some connection with this non-Habsburg being brought here, but the exact reason is unclear. The last item interred here is the urn with the viscera of Archduke [[Archduke Franz Karl of Austria|Franz Karl]]{{Bioxref|78}}, father of Emperor [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Franz Joseph]], in 1878. ==List of persons buried in the Ducal Crypt== [[Image:Stephansdom old Ducal Vault 1739.png|thumb|In the Original Crypt, the urns and sarcophagi are shown in disarray in this 1739 engraving. The new chamber was added a dozen years later, connecting through the wall to the left. The cross arrangement engraved in the wall was moved to the new chamber.]] The Ducal Crypt shelters the bodies of: *{{Biohead|1|King '''[[Frederick the Fair|Frederick III of the Romans]]''' (1286–1330)}} ''"the handsome"'' son of King [[Albert I of Germany|Albert I]], father of Duke [[Albert II, Duke of Austria|Albert II]] and grandfather of Duke Rudolf IV.{{Bioxref|3}} His remains were moved here in 1782 when the [[Carthusian]] monastery he founded at [[Mauerbach]], his original burial place, was closed during the [[anti-clerical]] reforms of Emperor [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]] "Sunny". *{{Biohead|2|Duke '''Friedrich''' (1347–1362)}}, second son of Duke [[Albert II, Duke of Austria|Albert II]] and the 15-year-old brother of Rudolf IV.{{Bioxref|3}} *{{Biohead|3|Duke '''[[Rudolf IV, Duke of Austria|Rudolf IV]]''' (1339–1365)}} ''"the founder,"'' eldest son of Duke [[Albert II, Duke of Austria|Albert II]]. Rudolf commissioned the present cathedral, and founded the [[University of Vienna]] before his death in Milan at age 25. He was originally entombed in S. Giovanni in Concha and later moved to here. The University lays a wreath on his tomb every 12 March to commemorate its founding by him. *{{Biohead|4|Duchess '''[[Katharine of Bohemia]]''' (19 August 1342 - 26 April 1395)}} wife of Rudolf IV{{Bioxref|3}} and daughter of Emperor [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles IV]]. After the death of Rudolf she married [[Otto V, Duke of Bavaria]]. *{{Biohead|5|Duke '''[[Albert III, Duke of Austria|Albert III]]''' (1349–1395)}} ''"with the pigtail,"'' third son of Duke [[Albert II, Duke of Austria|Albert II]] and younger brother of Rudolf IV.{{Bioxref|3}} Died at age 46. *{{Biohead|6|Duke '''[[Albert IV, Duke of Austria|Albert IV]]''' (1377–1404)}} son of Albert III.{{Bioxref|5}} Died at age 27. *{{Biohead|7|Duke '''[[William, Duke of Austria|Wilhelm]]''' (1370–1406)}} oldest son of Rudolf IVs youngest brother, [[Leopold III, Duke of Austria|Leopold III]]. *{{Biohead|8|Duke '''[[Leopold IV, Duke of Austria|Leopold IV]]''' (1371–1411)}} ''"the fat"'' younger son of Rudolf IVs youngest brother, Leopold III. *{{Biohead|9|Duke '''George''' (1435–1435)}} infant son of Duke [[Albert II of Germany|Albert V]]. *{{Biohead|11|Archduke '''Karl''' (1565–1566)}} 9-month-old son of Emperor [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian II]]. *{{Biohead|12|Archduke '''Ferdinand''' (1551–1552)}} 15-month-old son of Emperor Maximilian II. *{{Biohead|13|Archduchess '''Maria''' (1564–1564)}} one-month-old daughter of Emperor Maximilian II. *{{Biohead|14|Queen '''[[Elisabeth of Austria (1554-1592)|Elisabeth]]''' (1554–1592)}} Widow of King [[Charles IX of France]] and daughter of Emperor Maximilian II. In 1782 her body was moved here from the convent she had founded. *{{Biohead|15|Duchess '''Anna''' (1645–1646)|Dukes of Lorraine family tree}} young daughter of Duke [[Nicholas II, Duke of Lorraine]], a former Cardinal. *{{Biohead|16|Empress '''[[Eleonore Gonzaga|Eleanor of Gonzaga]]''' (1598–1655)}} second wife of Emperor [[Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand II]].{{Bioxref|19}} Her remains were moved here in 1782 from the [[Carmelite]] convent ''"Siebenbüchnerinnen"'' in Vienna that she had founded. Gated niches in the original chamber (outside the entrance to the previous chamber) [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927202413/http://www.deca-forum.net/deca-cgi/getdoc_e.pl?DEF=d%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Chida%3BDATEN%3Dd%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Cdata%3BTHE%3Dd%3A%5Cdata%5Cdeca%5Cidx%3BUSER%3Dbild%3BDOK_TPL%3Ddeca_doc_e.tpl%3BLIST_TPL%3Ddeca_list_e.tpl%3BFCT%3Dg%3Bikufo%3D%3BN_kufo%3D0%3BR_kufo%3D%3D%3Biauen%3D%3BN_auen%3D1%3BR_auen%3D%3D%3Bi024%3Dwien%3BN_024%3D2%3BR_024%3D%3D%3Bi025%3DStephansdom%3BN_025%3D3%3BR_025%3D%3D%3Bi031e%3D%3BN_031e%3D4%3BR_031e%3D%3D%3Bi029%3D%3BN_029%3D5%3BR_029%3D%3D%3Bi037%3D%3BN_037%3D6%3BR_037%3D%3D%3Bi038%3D%3BN_038%3D7%3BR_038%3D%3D%3Bi039%3D%3BN_039%3D8%3BR_039%3D%3D%3Bi040e%3D%3BN_040e%3D9%3BR_040e%3D%3D%3Bi027%3DKatakomben%20-%20KA%20Herzogsgruft%3BN_027%3D10%3BR_027%3D%3D&KEY=fot%20w0008731 protect 62 copper urns] containing the [[viscera]] ([[intestines]]) of various members of the [[Habsburg]] dynasty. *{{Biohead|17|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''[[Anna of Tyrol]]''' (4 October 1585–15 December 1618)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdx503}} Daughter of [[Ferdinand II, Duke of Tyrol]] and wife of her cousin Emperor Matthias{{Bioxref|18}} who was 28 years older than her. She provided in her will of 1617 for the establishment of a crypt for her and her husband in a Capuchin's Church to be built in Vienna, and died only one year later, at age 33 after seven years of a childless marriage and is buried in tomb 1 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] she founded. Her heart is in urn 1 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]]. [[File:Lucas van Valckenborch - Emperor Matthias as Archduke, with baton.jpg|thumb|'''Emperor Matthias''' is the first emperor whose viscera are deposited here. They were brought to the Ducal Crypt from their original resting place over 20 years later, after the testament of emperor-elect King Ferdinand IV of the Romans had set the precedent for honoring these three churches with the remains of the members of the Imperial Family.]] *{{Biohead|18|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor|Matthias]]''' (1557–1619)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdx503}} Third son of Emperor [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian II]]. Once governor of the [[Austrian Netherlands]], he wrested power over Austria, Hungary and Moravia from his inept brother Emperor [[Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor|Rudolf II]] in 1608 and inherited the rest in 1612. He died, age 62, only three months after his wife Empress Anna.{{Bioxref|17}} He is buried in tomb 2 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]] and his heart is in urn 2 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|19|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand II]]''' (1578–1637)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdx503}} Eldest son of Archduke [[Charles II of Austria|Charles II of Styria]]. He died at age 62. His heart is in urn 3 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in the [https://web.archive.org/web/20120716180709/http://www.kaisergruft.at/anhang/graz.htm Grazer Dom], [[Graz]]. *{{Biohead|20|''(Viscera of)'' King '''[[Ferdinand IV of Germany|Ferdinand IV of the Romans]]''' (8 September 1633 - 9 July 1654)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Eldest son of Emperor Ferdinand III.{{Bioxref|21}} He died two months before his 21st birthday. His heart is in urn 4 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 29 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. He established the tradition of burial of different parts in three separate Vienna churches. *{{Biohead|21|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Ferdinand III, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand III]]''' (13 July 1608 - 2 April 1657)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Third son of Emperor Ferdinand II.{{Bioxref|19}} He died during his 49th year and is buried in tomb 27 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|22|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Ferdinand Josef Alois''' (1657–1658)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant son of Emperor Ferdinand III.{{Bioxref|21}} He is buried in tomb 6 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|23|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''[[Archduke Leopold Wilhelm of Austria|Leopold Wilhelm]]''' (6 April 1614 - 20 November 1662)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdx503}} Son of Emperor Ferdinand II.{{Bioxref|19}} Named at age 13 to take over his uncle [[Leopold V of Austria (Habsburg)|Leopold's]] renounced see at Halberstaedt (when he became 22, this was confirmed by the Pope) and later became also [[Bishop of Olomouc]], [[Bishop of Breslau]], and Grand Master of the [[Teutonic Knights]]. He died at age 48. His heart is in urn 5 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 115 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|24|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''[[Karl Joseph of Austria|Karl Joseph]]''' (7 August 1649 - 27 January 1664)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Son of Emperor Ferdinand III{{Bioxref|21}} and Empress Maria Leopoldina, who died during his birth. [[Bishop of Olomouc]] and Grand Master of the [[Teutonic Knights]] at age 13 as heir to his uncle, Archduke Leopold Wilhelm.{{Bioxref|23}} The art collection he inherited from Archduke Leopold Wilhelm{{Bioxref|23}} became the foundation of the [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]]. Died at age 15. He is buried in tomb 116 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|25|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Ferdinand Wenzel Josef''' (1667–1668)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant son of Emperor Leopold I{{Bioxref|41}} and Empress Margarita Teresa.{{Bioxref|29}} He is buried in tomb 7 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. **'''26''' ''(Heart of)'' Archduke Ferdinand Wenzel Josef. *{{Biohead|27|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Johann Leopold''' (1670)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant son of Emperor Leopold I{{Bioxref|41}} and Empress Margarita Teresa.{{Bioxref|29}} He is buried in tomb 8 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|28|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Anna Antonie''' (1672)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant daughter of Emperor Leopold I{{Bioxref|41}} and Empress Margarita Teresa.{{Bioxref|29}} She is buried in tomb 10 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|29|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''Margarita Teresa''' (12 August 1651–12 March 1673)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Niece and first wife of Emperor Leopold I{{Bioxref|41}} at age 15, dead at 22. Her heart is in urn 6 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 20 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|30|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Anna Maria Sophie''' (1674)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant daughter of Emperor Leopold I{{Bioxref|41}} and Empress Claudia Felicitas.{{Bioxref|31}} She is buried in tomb 11 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|31|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''Claudia Felicitas''' (30 May 1653 - 8 April 1676)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Second wife of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} Her 22-year-old body, by her own request, is dressed in the habit of a Dominican nun and is entombed beside her mother in the Dominican Church in Vienna. Her heart is in urn 24 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|32|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Josefa Klementina''' (1675–1676)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant daughter of Emperor Leopold I{{Bioxref|41}} and Empress Claudia Felicitas.{{Bioxref|31}} Her heart is in a gold and silver urn atop her mother's sarcophagus in the Dominican Church. She is buried in tomb 12 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|33|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''Eleonora Magdalena of Mantua-Nevers-Gonzaga''' (18 November 1630 - 6 December 1686)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Third wife of Emperor Ferdinand III.{{Bioxref|21}} She was 56 when she died. Her heart is in urn 7 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 19 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|34|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Margareta''' (1690–1691)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant daughter of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} She is buried in tomb 14 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. **'''35''' ''(Heart of)'' Archduchess Maria Margareta *{{Biohead|36|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Antonia''' (18 January 1669 - 24 December 1692)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Daughter of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} She died at age 23. Her heart is in urn 8 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 28 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|37|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Theresia''' (1684–1696)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Twelve-year-old daughter of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} Her heart is in urn 9 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 25 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|38|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Leopold Joseph''' (1700–1701)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Infant son of Emperor Joseph I.{{Bioxref|42}} He is buried in tomb 33 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. **'''39''' ''(Heart of)'' Archduke Leopold Joseph *{{Biohead|40|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Josepha''' (1687–1703)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Sixteen-year-old daughter of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} Her heart is in urn 10 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 16 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. [[File:Benjamin von Block 001.jpg|thumb|'''Emperor Leopold I'''{{Bioxref|41}} enlarged the [[Imperial Crypt|Imperial Crypt at the Kapuzinerkirche]] and established the tradition of burying members of the Imperial Family in these three churches in Vienna, following the precedent set in 1654 by King [[Ferdinand IV of Germany|Ferdinand IV of the Romans]].]] *{{Biohead|41|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold I]]''' (9 June 1640 - 5 May 1705)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Second son of Emperor Ferdinand III{{Bioxref|21}} and father of Emperors Joseph I{{Bioxref|42}} and Karl VI.{{Bioxref|48}} He reigned 48 years. He was involved in wars ranging from the defense of western Europe against conquest by the Muslims, to the [[War of the Spanish Succession]] to place his second son{{Bioxref|48}} on the Spanish throne when the Spanish branch of the [[Habsburg]] dynasty died out in 1700. Leopold died a few weeks before his 65th birthday. His heart is in urn 11 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 37 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|42|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Joseph I, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph I]]''' (1678–1711)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Son of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} He died at age 33 after a short reign of six years. His heart is in urn 12 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 35 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|43|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Leopold Johann''' (13 April 1716 - 4 November 1716)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Prince of Asturias. Six-month-old only son of Emperor Karl VI.{{Bioxref|48}} He is buried in tomb 30 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. **'''44''' ''(Heart of)'' Archduke Leopold Johann. *{{Biohead|45|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Amalia''' (5 April 1724–19 April 1730)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Six-year-old youngest daughter of Emperor Karl VI.{{Bioxref|48}} She is buried in tomb 23 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|46|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Marie Elisabeth''' Amalie Antonie Josephe Gabriele Johanna Agathe (February 5, 1737 - June 7, 1740)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Three-years old, eldest daughter of Emperor Franz I Stephen{{Bioxref|56}} and Empress Maria Theresa.{{Bioxref|57}} She is buried in tomb 48 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. **'''47''' ''(Heart of)'' Archduchess Marie Elisabeth. *{{Biohead|48|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Karl VI]]''' (1 October 1685 - 20 October 1740)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Younger son of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} He died at age 55 after a reign of 29 years. His heart is in urn 13 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 40 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|49|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Marie Caroline''' Ernestine Antonie Johanna Josephe (January 12, 1740 - January 25, 1741)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Third daughter of Emperor Franz I Stephen{{Bioxref|56}} and Empress Maria Theresa.{{Bioxref|57}} Died at age 1 year. She is buried in tomb 53 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. **'''50''' ''(Heart of)'' Archduchess Marie Caroline. *{{Biohead|51|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''[[Archduchess Maria Elisabeth of Austria (governor)|Maria Elisabeth]]''' (1680–1741)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Regent of the Austrian Netherlands. Daughter of Emperor Leopold I.{{Bioxref|41}} Dead at age 61. Her heart is in urn 14 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 38 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. The container here for her viscera is of an unusual form, being a flat box instead of the more usual pot shape. *{{Biohead|52|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''[[Maria Anna of Austria (1718-1744)|Maria Anna]]''' (14 September 1718–16 December 1744)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} 26-year-old daughter of Emperor Karl VI.{{Bioxref|48}} Her heart is in urn 15 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 39 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|53|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''[[Elisabeth Christina of Braunschweig-Wolfenbüttel]]''' (28 August 1691 - 21 December 1750)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27}} Wife (1708) of Emperor Karl VI{{Bioxref|48}} and mother of Empress Maria Theresa.{{Bioxref|57}} Died at age 59. Her heart is in urn 17 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 36 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. [[Image:Stephansdom new Ducal Vault 1758.png|thumb|The New Chamber, as shown in this 1758 engraving, is substantially how it looks today. The window behind the sarcophagus of Duke Rudolf IV has a long sill sloping to the ground above to provide light. The urns containing viscera have now been moved to the adjoining Original Chamber.]] *{{Biohead|54|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Karl Joseph''' Emanuel Johann Nepomuck Anton Prokop (1 February 1745–18 January 1761)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Second son of Emperor Franz I Stephen{{Bioxref|56}} and Empress Maria Theresa.{{Bioxref|57}} Died of smallpox shortly before his 16th birthday. His heart is in urn 18 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 44 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|55|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess Marie '''Johanna Gabriele''' Josephe Antonie (4 February 1750 - 23 December 1762|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Eighth daughter of Emperor Franz I Stephen{{Bioxref|56}} and Empress Maria Theresa.{{Bioxref|57}} Died of smallpox at age 12. Her heart is in urn 19 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 45 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|56|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Francis I, Holy Roman Emperor|Franz I Stephen]]''' (Lunéville 8 December 1708 - Innsbruck 18 August 1765)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Duke of Lorraine and Grand Duke of Tuscany. Husband of Empress Maria Theresa,{{Bioxref|57}} he died at age 56 after nominally being Emperor for 25 years. His heart is in urn 20 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 55 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|57|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''[[Maria Theresa of Austria|Maria Theresa]]''' (13 May 1717 - 29 November 1780)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Eldest surviving descendent of Emperor Karl VI,{{Bioxref|48}}[[#Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFerdinand27|→Family Tree]] her ascension was contested and officially the crown of the Empire went to her husband (1736) Emperor Franz I Stephen.{{Bioxref|56}} but she held Hungary and Bohemia as Queen in her own right. Dying at age 63, her forty years' reign is thought of by the Austrians as the British think of [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]]: the golden years of power, prestige and empire. Her heart is in urn 21 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 56 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|58|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Louise Elisabeth''' (Vienna 18 February 1790 - Vienna 24 June 1791)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Infant first daughter of Emperor Franz II and Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|70}} Her heart is in urn 22 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 66 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. [[File:Janos Donath 001.png|thumb|'''Emperor Leopold II''' spent little time in Vienna even during his two-year reign, but is now buried in three different Viennese churches.]] *{{Biohead|59|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold II]]''' (1747–1792)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartLeopold113}} Third son of Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|57}} [[#ZegelChartMTheresia56|→Family Tree]] Most of his career was spent in Florence, reforming the governance there as Grand Duke of Tuscany, and only his final two years were as Emperor. He died at age 45. His heart is in urn 23 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 113 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|60|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''[[Maria Louise of Sicily|Maria Ludovika]]''' (24 November 1745–15 May 1792)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartLeopold113}} Originally contracted to marry Empress Maria Theresia's{{Bioxref|57}} second son, Archduke Karl Joseph,{{Bioxref|54}} his early death diverted her instead to the third son, who later became Emperor Leopold II.{{Bioxref|59}} In the course of 21 years, she bore her not-always-faithful husband 16 children, among them Emperor Franz II, and Archduke Karl the victor of Aspern. Grieving for her husband, she outlived him by only two months leaving many small children. Her 46-year-old heart is in urn 24 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 114 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|61|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess Maria '''Karoline Leopoldine''' Franziska Theresia Josepha Medarde (Vienna 8 June 1794 - Vienna 16 March 1795)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Infant daughter of Emperor Franz II and Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|70}} Her heart is in urn 25 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 95 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|62|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Alexander Leopold''' Johann Joseph (Poggio Imperiale 14 August 1772 - Laxenburg 12 July 1795)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartLeopold113}} Fourth son of Emperor Leopold II{{Bioxref|59}} and Empress Maria Ludovika.{{Bioxref|60}} Palatine of Hungary. Died at 23. His heart is in urn 26 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 64 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|63|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess [[Marie Christine of Austria|'''Maria Christina''' Johanna Josephe Antonie]] ''("Mimi")'' (3 May 1742 - 24 June 1798)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Favorite daughter of Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|57}} Wife of Duke Albert of Teschen.{{Bioxref|75}} The famous and moving monument he erected to her memory is in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]]. She died of Typhus at age 56. Her heart is in urn 28 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 112 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|64|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Maria Amalia''' Josephe Johanna Katharina Theresia (Florence 15 October 1780 - Vienna 25 December 1798)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartLeopold113}} Daughter of Emperor Leopold II{{Bioxref|59}} and Empress Maria Ludovika.{{Bioxref|60}} Died at 18. Her heart is in urn 27 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 65 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|65|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Caroline Ludovika''' Leopoldine (Vienna 9 December 1795 - Schloß Hetzendorf 30 June 1799)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Fourth daughter of Emperor Franz II and Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|70}} Died at 3. Her heart is in urn 29 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 87 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|66|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''[[Maximilian Franz of Austria|Maximilian Franz]]''' (8 December 1756 - 26 July 1801)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Youngest son of Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|57}} Grand Master of the [[Teutonic Knights]], [[Bishop of Münster]] and Elector-Archbishop of Cologne. Died at 45. His heart is in urn 30 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 118 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|67|''(Viscera of)'' Archduchess '''Karoline Ferdinanda''' (Florence 2 August 1793 - Vienna 5 January 1802)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartTuscan}} Daughter of [[Ferdinand III, Grand Duke of Tuscany]] and Luisa Maria Amelia Teresa of Naples.{{Bioxref|68}} Died at 9. Her heart is in urn 31 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 79 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|68|''(Viscera of)'' Grand Duchess '''[[Luisa Maria Amelia Teresa of Naples|Luisa Maria]]''' (Naples 27 July 1773 - Vienna 19 September 1802)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Daughter of Queen Maria Karolina of Naples and Sicily.{{Bioxref|73}} First wife (1790) of [[Ferdinand III, Grand Duke of Tuscany]] [[Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartTuscan|→Family Tree]]. Died in childbirth at 29. Her heart is in urn 32 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried along with her stillborn son in tomb 84 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|69|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke [[Archduke Ferdinand of Austria-Este|'''Ferdinand Karl Anton''' Joseph Johann Stanislaus]] (1 June 1754 - 24 December 1806)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Fourth son of Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|57}} Governor of Lombardy and, later, the [[Austrian Netherlands]]. Founder of the House of Austria-Este. His 52-year-old heart is in urn 34 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 105 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|70|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''[[Maria Teresa Carolina Giuseppina of Naples and Sicily|Maria Teresa of Naples and Sicily]]''' (Naples 6 June 1772 - Vienna 13 April 1807)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Second wife (1790) at age 18 of Emperor Franz II. Mother of Empress Maria Louise (second wife of Napoleon), Emperor Ferdinand,{{Bioxref|77}} and all subsequent children of her husband. Because her mother{{Bioxref|73}} was a sister of her husband's father{{Bioxref|59}} the couple were first cousins. [[#ZegelChartMTheresia56|→Family Tree (ancestors)]] She died at age 34 of tuburcular [[pleurisy]]. Her heart is in urn 35 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 60 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|71|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Joseph Franz''' Leopold (Vienna 9 April 1799 - Laxenburg 30 June 1807)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Second son of Emperor Franz II and Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|70}} Died at 18. His heart is in urn 36 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 69 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|72|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''Johann Nepomuk Karl''' (Vienna 29 August 1805 - Vienna 19 February 1809)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Fourth son of Emperor Franz II and Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|70}} Died at 4. His heart is in urn 37 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 71 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|73|''(Viscera of)'' Queen '''[[Maria Karolina of Naples and Sicily]]''' 1752–1814)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Daughter of Empress Maria Theresia.{{Bioxref|57}} Wife of King [[Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies]]. Her heart is in urn 38 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 107 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. [[Image:Francesco Hayez 047.jpg|thumb|'''Emperor Ferdinand''',{{Bioxref|77}} painted at age 40, is the last emperor to have his viscera deposited in the Ducal Crypt.]] *{{Biohead|74|''(Viscera of)'' Empress '''[[Maria Ludovika of Austria-Este]]''' (Monza 14 December 1787 - Verona 7 April 1816)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Third wife (1808) at age 20 of 40-year-old cousin Emperor Franz II, she contracted [[tuberculosis]] shortly after their wedding, suffering from it for the eight years of marriage before dying at age 28. Her heart is in urn 39 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and she is buried in tomb 58 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|75|''(Viscera of)'' Duke '''[[Albert of Saxony-Teschen]]''' (11 July 1738–10 February 1822)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartMTheresia56}} Husband of Archduchess Maria Christina.{{Bioxref|63}} The [[Albertina (Vienna)|Albertina]] museum, in his former palace, is named for him because his collection of paintings formed the nucleus of the museum. The oldest of those represented here, he died at age 84. His heart is in urn 40 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 111 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|76|''(Viscera of)'' Prince '''[[Napoleon II of France|Franz Joseph Karl, Duke of Reichstadt]]''' (1811–1832)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Twenty-one-year-old son of [[Napoléon Bonaparte]] and Empress [[Marie Louise, Duchess of Parma|Maria Louise]] (daughter of Emperor Franz II.) His heart is in urn 42 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]]. His body was originally buried in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]] but in 1940, on the orders of [[Adolf Hitler]], it was moved to [[Les Invalides]] in [[Paris]] to rest with his father's. *{{Biohead|77|''(Viscera of)'' Emperor '''[[Ferdinand I of Austria]]''' (1793–1875)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} First son of Emperor Franz II. Mentally retarded, he abdicated after a nominal reign of 12 years and spent the remainder of his 82-year-long life in Prague. His heart is in urn 53 in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]] and he is buried in tomb 62 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. *{{Biohead|78|''(Viscera of)'' Archduke '''[[Archduke Franz Karl of Austria|Franz Karl]]''' (1802–1878)|Imperial Crypt#ZegelChartFranz57}} Third son of Emperor Franz II. When his elder brother Emperor Ferdinand{{Bioxref|77}} abdicated in 1848, he stood aside so that his son, Emperor [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Franz Joseph]], could succeed to the throne instead. Great grandfather of the last reigning emperor, Emperor [[Karl I of Austria|Karl I]]. Aged 76 when he died, his viscera are the last interred here, and his heart was the last to be placed in the [[Herzgruft]] in the [[Augustinian Church, Vienna|Augustinerkirche]], where it occupies urn 54. He is buried in tomb 135 in the [[Imperial Crypt]] in the [[Kapuzinerkirche]]. ==See also== *[[Imperial Crypt]] *[[Herzgruft]] ==References== * {{cite book | first = Hubert | last = Kritzer | author2 = Schaden, Christine | year = 2003 | title = '''Der Friedhof von Sankt Stephan''' | url = http://www.univie.ac.at/kunstgeschichte-tutorium/stephansplatz/05friedhof.ppt | edition = Institut für Kunstgeschichte | publisher = University of Vienna | location = Vienna | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040627045427/http://www.univie.ac.at/kunstgeschichte-tutorium/stephansplatz/05friedhof.ppt | archivedate = 2004-06-27 | df = }} (in German) * {{cite book | first = Reinhard H. | last = Gruber | year = 2001 | title = '''St. Stephan's Cathedral in Vienna''' | edition = 2nd. | publisher = Stephansdom | location = Vienna}} * {{cite book | first = Paul|last=Theroff|title=An Online Gotha|url=http://www.angelfire.com/realm/gotha/gotha/austria.html|chapter=Austria}} {{coord|48.20833|N|16.37278|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Innere Stadt]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Vienna]] [[Category:Cemeteries in Vienna]] [[Category:Sarcophagi]] [[Category:Burial sites of the House of Habsburg]] [[Category:St. Stephen's Cathedral, Vienna]]

[[File:Flag of Adelaide.svg|right|thumb|250px|Flag ratio: 1:2]]
The armorial flag of Adelaide was approved on August 2, 1982. It replaced the de facto decoration of the coat of arms on a white background which had been flown outside of the town hall and was used during special occasions prior to the replacement. The new flag was prepared by College of Arms and took its symbols from the city's coat of arms.<ref>[http://www.adelaidecitycouncil.com/your-council/role-of-council/175-years-of-council/history-of-council History of Council - The Armorial Flag], City of Adelaide website</ref><ref>[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/au-sa-ad.html The Armorial Flag], Description of the armorial flag of Adelaide</ref>
The flag contains a navy blue background divided into four quarters by a [[Saint George's Cross]] outlined in [[gold]] overlain with the Arms of the City of [[Adelaide]]. The flag is bordered on three sides by diagonal blue and gold stripes.<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Council|url=http://www.adelaidecitycouncil.com/your-council/role-of-council/175-years-of-council/history-of-council/|publisher=Adelaide City Council|accessdate=22 January 2015}}</ref><ref>http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/au-sa-ad.html</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Adelaide|Heraldry and Vexillology}} *[[Coat of arms of Adelaide]] *[[List of Australian flags#Cities_and_areas|List of Australian flags]]

{{About|the Frederic Leighton painting|the 1997 trance song by BT|Flaming June (song)}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Flaming_June,_by_Frederic_Lord_Leighton_(1830-1896).jpg | image_size=320px | title=Flaming June | artist=[[Frederic Leighton]] | year= | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial=47 | width_imperial=47 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Ponce, Puerto Rico]] | museum=[[Museo de Arte de Ponce]] }} '''''Flaming June''''' is a painting by Sir [[Frederic Leighton]], produced in 1895. Painted with [[oil paint]]s on a {{convert|47|x|47|in|adj=on}} square canvas, it is widely considered to be Leighton's [[Masterpiece|magnum opus]], showing his [[Classicism|classicist]] nature. It is thought that the woman portrayed alludes to the figures of sleeping [[nymph]]s and [[naiad]]s the [[Ancient Greek art|Greeks]] often sculpted.
''Flaming June'' disappeared from view in the early 1900s and was rediscovered only in the 1960s. It was auctioned shortly after, during a period of time known to be difficult for selling Victorian era paintings, where it failed to sell for its low reserve price of US$140 (the equivalent of $1,126 in modern prices). After the auction, it was promptly purchased by the [[Museo de Arte de Ponce]] in [[Ponce, Puerto Rico]], where it currently resides.
==Appraisal== ''Flaming June'' was first begun as a motif to adorn a marble bath in one of Leighton's other works, ''Summer Slumber''. He became so attached to the design that he decided to create it as a painting in its own right. {{Quote box|width=25em|align=right|quote=The funereal solemnity of Michelangelo's monumental nude has been considerably warmed up, by the Victorian painter, in the act of appropriating and adapting it. Leighton has arranged matters in such a way that, although clothed, his somnolent girl's many charms are alluringly displayed for the delectation of the viewer – who is implicitly put in the position of a voyeur... Her cheeks are flushed, reddened with a blush suggesting that somehow she knows she is being watched, even though she is sleeping.<ref name=AGD>{{cite web|first=Andrew |last=Graham-Dixon|title= ITP 266: Flaming June by Frederic Leighton |date=5 June 2005|work= Sunday Telegraph|authorlink=Andrew Graham-Dixon|url=http://www.andrewgrahamdixon.com/archive/itp-266-flaming-june-by-frederic-leighton.html}}</ref>}} According to art historian [[Andrew Graham-Dixon]] "her pose is loosely modelled on that of Michelangelo's famous statue of ''[[Night (Michelangelo)|Night]]'', in the Medici Tombs in Florence, which Leighton regarded as one of the supreme achievements of Western art."<ref name=AGD/> The position of the sleeping woman gave Leighton a great deal of trouble. He made several preliminary sketches to determine the way in which she should lie; in particular he had difficulty making the angle of her right arm look natural. His studies show that the picture went through at least four evolutionary sketches before Leighton came to the end result. Out of these studies, four are nude and one is draped.<ref>Cf. T. Barringer & [[Elizabeth Prettejohn|E. Prettejohn]], ''Frederic Leighton: Antiquity, Renaissance, Modernity'', Yale University Press (1999), ''s.v.'' "Flaming June".</ref> The draped figure looks the least lifelike, demonstrating Leighton's need to draw from a naked model to achieve a fidelity to nature.
The toxic [[oleander]] branch in the top right possibly symbolizes the fragile link between sleep and death.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/great-works/leighton-frederic-flaming-june-1895-814972.html|title= Leighton, Frederic: ''Flaming June'' (1895)|work= The Independent|date=25 April 2008}}</ref>
''Flaming June'' has become Leighton's most recognisable picture. [[Samuel Courtauld (industrialist)|Samuel Courtauld]], founder of the [[Courtauld Institute]], called it “the most wonderful painting in existence”.<ref name=guard/> The realism of the transparent material worn by the sleeping woman, the stunningly rich colours and the perfectly recreated marble surround are characteristic of Leighton's work, as is his use of natural light. He allows the sunset in the background to appear as molten gold.<ref>A. Weidinger, ''Magnificent Extravagance – Frederic, Lord Leighton's Flaming June 1894–95'', [[Belvedere, Vienna|Belvedere]] (2010), ''passim''.</ref>
==Provenance== The painting's first owners, ''[[The Graphic]]'' magazine, bought it to create a high-quality reproduction which was given away as a Christmas gift in 1895. When Leighton died in January 1896 it was put in their office window which was passed by the funeral procession. It was loaned to the [[Ashmolean Museum]] in early 1900s, its whereabouts after this are unknown; it was rediscovered in a Battersea home in the early 1960s, boxed in over a chimney. [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] saw it soon afterwards in a shop on the Kings Road, but his grandmother refused to lend him the £50 asking price, stating: "I will not have Victorian junk in my flat".<ref name=guard>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/jun/20/flaming-june-frederic-lord-leighton-house-museum|work=Guardian|title= Leighton's Flaming June to go on display in studio where it was painted |date=20 June 2016|author=Maev Kennedy}}</ref>
In 1963 [[Luis A. Ferré]]{{snd}}the noted Puerto Rican [[industrialist]] and politician, who would be elected [[governor of Puerto Rico|governor]] five years later{{snd}}was on a trip around Europe, engaged in purchasing paintings and sculptures for the [[Museo de Arte de Ponce]] in Puerto Rico, which he had founded. Passing by The Maas Gallery, London in 1963, Ferré was enthralled by the work, and offered to pay £2,000 for the painting.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Featured Picture Details|url = http://www.maasgallery.co.uk/component/content/article/68|website = www.maasgallery.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-08-20|last = Ellis}}</ref> Antonio Luis Ferré, the industrialist's son, many years later related that his father spent a sleepless night worried that, in the final stages of the transaction, [[Jeremy Maas]], then owner of The Maas Gallery and ''Flaming June'', would retract his offer and sell it to another buyer.<ref>Antonio Luis Ferré, article in ''[[El Nuevo Día]]'', 22 April 2001.</ref> Ferré prevailed, and ''Flaming June'' was taken to the Museo de Arte de Ponce and prominently displayed. With the renewed interest in Victorian art, it was also loaned to important exhibitions around the world. ''Flaming June'' was on display at the [[Museo del Prado]] in Madrid in 2008, the [[Staatsgalerie Stuttgart]] in Germany in 2009 and in the [[Frick Collection]] in 2015.
In 2015 an original pencil and chalk study for the painting{{snd}}the model's head{{snd}}was found on the back of a bedroom door in the mansion inherited by [[Bamber Gascoigne]] after the death of his great aunt [[Mary Innes-Ker, Duchess of Roxburghe]].<ref>{{citation|newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 May 2015 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/01/pre-raphaelite-study-discovered-behind-door-in-english-mansion |title=Pre-Raphaelite study behind door in English mansion |accessdate=3 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YFK52aZ3?url=http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/01/pre-raphaelite-study-discovered-behind-door-in-english-mansion |archivedate=3 May 2015 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
In 2016 the painting was loaned to the [[Leighton House Museum]] in Kensington, and was displayed in the studio where it was created.<ref name=guard/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/goingout/arts/jimmy-page-welcomes-flaming-june-painting-back-to-kensington-a3385021.html|title=Jimmy Page welcomes Flaming June painting back to Kensington|date=2 November 2016|publisher=''Evening Standard''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/flaming-june-will-brighten-the-darkness-vfm7vfkrx|title=Flaming June will brighten the darkness|publisher=''The Times''}}</ref>
==Models== While the body of the woman remains a mystery, there is speculation that the face is that of either of Leighton’s two favourite models in the 1890s, [[Dorothy Dene]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2015/06/flaming-june-identity-frederic-lord-leighton-dorothy-dene|title=The Strange Journey of One of the World’s Most Famous Paintings|first=Patrick|last=Monahan|publisher=''Vanity Fair''}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/11236508/Dorothy-Dene-Lord-Leightons-secret-lover.html|title=Dorothy Dene: Lord Leighton's secret lover?|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> or Mary Lloyd.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jill Berk Jiminez|title=Dictionary of Artists' Models|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ogFYAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA593|date=15 October 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-95914-2|pages=593–}}</ref><ref>[http://www.claphamsociety.com/Articles/Article2/original/LHS_2_PIC_9.html ''Apollo Magazine'']</ref>
Mary Lloyd was the daughter of an impoverished country squire. She came to London and established a highly successful career as an artist's model, posing only for the head and hands, and not nude – an important distinction. She started posing for Leighton in about 1892, was requested to come to pose in January 1895 for Leighton’s ''Lachrymae'' (1894–1895). She is probably also the model for his ''<nowiki>'</nowiki>Twixt Hope and Fear'' (c. 1895).

{{Infobox artwork/wikidata}} '''''Flower still life with a watch''''' is a 1663 floral painting by [[Willem van Aelst]]. It is in the collection of the [[Mauritshuis]] and exhibited at the [[Prince William V Gallery|Gallery Prince Willem V]].<ref name=RKD>{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/explore/images/7326 |title=Flower still life with a watch, 1663 gedateerd|publisher=[[RKD]]|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref>
==Early history and creation== This work was painted in Amsterdam where it was signed and dated ''Guill.mo van Aelst. 1663.'' Van Aelst had recently returned from Italy and thus signed as "Guillelmo" rather than Willem. He remained in Amsterdam until his death and was a strong influence on other Amsterdam flower painters, including Rachel Ruysch.
==Description and interpretation== The work shows a watch with a blue ribbon attached. It is not clear which watchmaker designed it. The bouquet shows [[Rosa gallica]], [[Poppy (flower)|poppy]], [[Pieris (butterfly)|Pieris]], [[Myosotis]], Gentiana, [[Viburnum opulus]], [[Tagetes lucida]], [[Tagetes patula]], [[butterfly]], [[Southern hawker|Southern Hawker]], and [[Calliphoridae]].<ref name=RKD/> The vase itself is an object created by [[Johannes Lutma]] in the [[auricular style]].<ref name=RKD/>
The painting follows in a tradition of Dutch and Flemish flower still life paintings showing a pocket watch attached to a blue ribbon with a wind-up key. This is one of many recurring symbols of the [[Vanitas]] genre that Van Aelst and others used: <gallery> File:Jan Davidsz. de Heem - Flower Still-life with Crucifix and Skull - WGA11259.jpg|Jan Davidsz de Heem, 1630s File:Jan van Kessel de Oude - Stilleven met bloemen in een glazen vaas, samen met een atalanta vlinder etc.jpg|Jan van Kessel the elder, 1652 File:Willem van Aelst - Vase of Flowers with Pocket Watch - WGA00050.jpg|Willem van Aelst, 1656 File:Willem van Aelst - Bloemenstilleven met horloge.jpg|Willem van Aelst, 1663 </gallery>
==Later history and influence== The painting is one of many from the Dutch Royal collection at [[Het Loo Palace]], Apeldoorn. It is registered there as early as 1757. [[William V, Prince of Orange]] took it to The Hague for his new 1774 gallery. It was in the gallery when its contents were taken to Paris as war booty during the French occupation. It was on show in the [[Louvre]] from 1795 until 1815, whereupon it was returned.

Sculpture: Bronze, steel | subject = | height_imperial = 13 | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = 23 | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | condition = "Well maintained" (1993) | city = [[Salem, Oregon]], United States | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{coord|44.93509|-123.03127|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = USA Oregon Salem#USA Oregon | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = Location in Salem, Oregon | owner = [[Willamette University]] | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Hatfield Fountain''''', formally the '''''Antoinette and Mark O. Hatfield Fountain''''' and nicknamed "'''Chicken Fountain'''",{{cite web|title=Antoinette and Mark O. Hatfield Fountain, (sculpture).|url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=141T5599T1T45.2941&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!325965~!12&ri=|publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]]|accessdate=September 28, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Hallie Ford Museum of Art and Salem: March 5, 2005|url=http://www.obsidians.org/reports/reports/2005/t030501.htm|publisher=Obsidians, Inc.|accessdate=September 29, 2015}} is an outdoor 1989 fountain and sculpture by [[Tom Hardy (artist)|Tom Hardy]], [[Lawrence Halprin]], and Scott Stickney, installed at [[Willamette University]] in [[Salem, Oregon]], United States. ==History== ''Hatfield Fountain'' was designed by Tom Hardy, [[Lawrence Halprin]], and Scott Stickney. It is named after Antoinette and [[Mark Hatfield]], a former Oregon senator and [[Willamette University]] alumnus,{{cite web|title=Virtual Tour: Hatfield Fountain|url=http://www.willamette.edu/virtual_tour/outdoors/locations/hatfield_fountain.html|publisher=[[Willamette University]]|accessdate=September 28, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610012404/http://www.willamette.edu/virtual_tour/outdoors/locations/hatfield_fountain.html|archivedate=June 10, 2015|df=}} and was dedicated on October 13, 1989. According to Willamette University, the fountain serves as a popular reference point for campus gatherings. The ''Hatfield Fountain'' is administered by Willamette University. In July 1993, the fountain was surveyed and deemed as "well maintained" by the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s "[[Save Outdoor Sculpture!]]" program. == Description == The work features two birds set on a fountain consisting of large stones arranged in two stacks, all set in a round basin. The concrete-and-stone fountain measures approximately {{Convert|13|ft|m}} tall and has a diameter of {{Convert|23|ft|m}}. One bird sits atop each stack; the bird on the shorter stack is set in a [[bird nest]] of rods and carrying a twig in its mouth, and the bird on the taller stack has its wings spread. The birds are made of steel rods and cut bronze or steel sheet; one measures approximately {{Convert|3|ft|m}} x {{Convert|2|ft|m}} x {{Convert|3|ft|m}}, and another measures approximately {{Convert|5|ft|m}} x {{Convert|2|ft|m}} x {{Convert|3|ft|m}}. Water flows from one of the stacks into the basin. A nearby plaque reads: {{Small|THE ANTOINETTE AND MARK O. HATFIELD / FOUNTAIN / GENEROUS GIFT / OF / CHARLES E. AND DOROTHY L. COOK / SCULPTURE AND DESIGN BY / TOM HARDY, LAWRENCE HALPRIN / AND SCOTT STICKNEY / DEDICATED OCTOBER 13, 1989}}. ==See also== {{Portal|Oregon|Visual arts}} * [[1989 in art]] * [[List of public art in Salem, Oregon]] * [[Untitled (Hardy)|''Untitled'' (Hardy)]], Eugene, Oregon (1952) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Commons category-inline|Hatfield Fountain}} * [http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMFHCY_Antoinette_and_Mark_O_Hatfield_Fountain_sculpture_Salem_Oregon Antoinette and Mark O.
